content:
There are at least three ways:

1) In your message compose window, press the Alt key if the menu isn't shown, then use the menu option File | Attach | Files(s) and browse to the attachment file;

2) Hit Ctrl+Shift+A to bring up a file browse window;

3) Simply drag and drop the file onto the Compose/Write window.
creator: rednoise

content: I'm not sure I understand your intention, but multiple folders can be selected in the Folders List by holding down the <Ctrl> key while clicking on non-contiguous ones, or while holding <Shift> and selecting a range. You can then right-click on the selection and use the <Move To> pop-up menu to move them to the top level of your Local Folders. The selection can also be drag-and-dropped to the top level of Local Folders.

content:
They seem to suggest contradictory settings:

https://www.skymesh.net.au/support/nbn-information/email-setup

Try these: incoming POP server mail.skymesh.com.au, 995, SSL/TLS, authentication = normal password, email address

outgoing SMTP server mail.skymesh.com.au, 465, SSL/TLS, authentication = no authentication

Those outgoing settings are very unusual, and it's stated at the bottom of the page to use

outgoing SMTP server mail.skymesh.com.au, 465, SSL/TLS, authentication = normal password, email address

which is the standard on port 465.

content:
Here are the steps:

  1. install thunderbird if not already installed, downloaded from thunderbird.net
  2. open the backup profile that you posted in Windows File explorer, highlight all and COPY all to clipboard
  3. in thunderbird, click help>troubleshootinginformation
  4. scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'
  5. now, paste contents of exported profile, overlaying contents of profile.
  6. if there is a compatibilitie.ini file, delete it
  7. restart thunderbird

content:
I just fixed this following the below instructions on a Google search for anyone else having this problem

Open the Registry Editor by typing regedit in the Run dialog (Windows Key + R) and clicking OK. Navigate to HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\WOW6432Node\Microsoft\Windows Messaging Subsystem. In the right-hand panel, check if a String Value (REG_SZ) named MAPI exists. If it does not exist, right-click in the blank space, select New > String Value, and name it MAPI. Double-click the MAPI string value and enter 1 in the Value data field, then click OK. For comprehensive MAPI support, some sources also suggest adding a MAPIX string value with a value of 1 in the same location. Close the Registry Editor and restart the application (or your computer) for the changes to take effect.

content:
There may be better approaches, but I'll share what I did for my account that was similar:

First, if this is an IMAP account, rightclick account name in folder pane, select 'subscribe' and unsubscribe from the one that is not used. Second, if that is not successful, log onto your account website and delete the unused account there when thunderbird is not running. Then, locate the profile folder and locate the folder there and delete it. On restarting thunderbird, it may be gone.

content:
These steps work on Windows, but I don't know about Mac:

  1. start thunderbird on old PC
  2. click tools>export and then click 'open profile folder'
  3. exit thunderbird
  4. copy profile content to external media
  5. install thunderbird on new pc, downloaded from thunderbird.net
  6. in receiving PC, click help>troubleshootinginformation
  7. scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'
  8. exit thunderbird
  9. now, paste contents of exported profile, overlaying contents of profile.
  10. if there is a compatibilitie.ini file, delete it
  11. restart thunderbird

content:
Try to start Windows 11 in safe mode with networking enabled.

Does the problem go away?

Windows safe mode disables anti-virus software. This is a troubleshooting step, not a solution.

I have made Thunderbird.exe and the Thunderbird folder exclusions, but it has made no apparent difference.

There is no point creating an exception for the program folder. You should create an exception for the Thunderbird profile though. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_how-to-find-your-profile

content:
Thunderbird's Account Hub feature is still labeled as "experimental". It usually picks correct settings for most major email hosts, but not necessarily for less common ones. The feature can be turned off in Tools | Settings | General | Account Hub. Disabling those options will let you manually enter the email provider's technical information.


The first thing you need to do is gather the correct settings. These can be gotten from your system administrators or the help web page. You will need to know:

- incoming server protocol (IMAP or POP3) - incoming server name - incoming server port - incoming server security type (SSL/TLS, STARTTLS, or none) - incoming server authentication method (usually "normal password")


- outgoing (SMTP) server name - outgoing (SMTP) server port - outgoing (SMTP) server port - outgoing (SMTP) server security type (SSL/TLS, STARTTLS, or none) - outgoing (SMTP) server authentication method (usually "normal password")

Plus your user ID and password.

Now, after disabling Account Hub, when you start the Add Account process you will have to opportunity to manually configure the server settings.

content: When you enter a domain address @cesconsult.com in the setup wizard, it 'guesses' a server address which is almost always the generic mail.<domain> and incorrect. Your domain is hosted on MS servers, so it is either configured as standard IMAP/SMTP or Exchange. Consult your sys. admin to find out the details.
creator: sfhowes

content:
Problem solved. For anyone else encountering this issue, manually configure the settings using IMAP. The following are the settings per Microsoft: Username: Your email address

Password: Your Microsoft account password. If your password is not being recognized, or if you want to add your Outlook.com account to a smart device like a home security camera, you may need an app password. Learn how to add your Outlook.com account to another mail app or smart device.

IMAP (Incoming) server: outlook.office365.com

IMAP port: 993

IMAP encryption: SSL/TLS

Authentication Method: OAuth2/Modern Auth


IMAP (Outgoing) server name: outlook.office365.com

IMAP port: 587

IMAP encryption: STARTTLS or SSL/TLS

Authentication Method: OAuth2/Modern Auth
creator: jrdehal

content: The outgoing SMTP server is smtp.office365.com, 587, STARTTLS, OAuth2, email address.
